newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: INTERVIEW - 3Com sees mergers in network industry.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - 3Com sees mergers in network industry.

text.p: The merger of U.S. networking products company 3Com and modem maker U.S. Robotics will change the industry by pushing other firms to combine, 3Com chief Eric Benhamou said on Thursday.
"There will be a shakeout. There will be a reaction on the part of smaller players to try and combine to get to a critical mass," Benhamou told Reuters in an interview.
3Com, which makes devices that control and link networks and connect personal computers to networks, and U.S. Robotics are merging through a stock deal valued at US$7.3 billion.

U.S. Robotics is the leading worldwide maker of computer modems for the consumer market. Benhamou said he expected a "small amount" of job losses from the total 13,000 employees as a result of the merger.

Expected to be completed in summer, the deal will result in the industry being dominated by two giants -- the merged 3Com with revenue of more than $5 billion and its main rival Cisco Systems Inc with sales of about US$4 billion.

Benhamou said there were already signs of an industry reaction, pointing to the announcement in late March by networking company Ascend Communications it would buy Cascade Communications for $3.7 billion.
Analysts say they also expect smaller networking companies like Bay Networks Inc and Shiva Corp to become acquisition targets.
But Benhamou said there was unikely to be another merger on the scale of 3Com and U.S. Robotics. Even with more mergers, companies would have to compete differently, he said.
"It really separates us a lot from everyone else. It brings us to the same revenues as Cisco. It gives us more technology coverage and channel coverage than anyone else," he said.

"There is going to be a visible difference between the top two vendors and the others. This has the effect of changing the landscape and separating us between the broad-based companies, of which we claim there are two, and the more narrowly-based companies who focus on specific segments," he said.

The merger with U.S. Robotics would not only give 3Com "end-to-end" solutions across LANS (local area networks) and WANS (wide area networks) but opportunities to develop unique products, like subsystems for personal computers, Benhamou said.
The merger could also see a greater presence of U.S. Robotics products in Asia.
"One thing we are going to explore is the possibility of building U.S. Robotics products in the Singapore plant," he said.

3Com has invested $98 million in the first phase of a Singapore plant to manufacture networking products, a logistics centre, regional support and data centre. The plant is expected to start operation in early 1998.
Benhamou said 3Com would make more acquisitions in future if there were new technologies that it preferred to purchase.
